docs.title: Welcome to the SODAS Documentation
docs.text: Find relevant documentation and information about SODAS here.

docs.title: Server
docs.text:
Welcome to the SODAS server.

Before you start using the server, please make sure that you read all the three pages in this part of the documentation:

  1. How to access the server
  2. How to setup a project and your developer environment
  3. How to use the computational resources through Slurm

docs.title: Access
docs.text: In order to access the server, you need to contact TBD with your basic information and SODAS affiliation, and they will setup up an account for you.

docs.title: Connecting to the server
docs.text:
First of all, you need to be connected to the university's VPN.

You can connect to the server using SSH, either through the terminal or VSCode.

docs.title: SSH
docs.text:
ssh -L <local-port>:localhost:<remote-port> <username>@sodashead01fl.unicph.domain

To connect locally to the server on port 8000 with the user abc123, do:

ssh -L 8000:localhost:8000 abc123@sodashead01fl.unicph.domain

docs.title: Transfer from local to server
docs.text:
scp /path/to/file <username>@sodashead01fl.unicph.domain:/path/to/destination

To move a text file in documents to your H-drive which is mounted on the server by default, do:

scp /documents/test.txt abc123@sodashead01fl.unicph.doman:/ucph/hdir

docs.title: Transfer file from server to local
docs.text:
scp <username>@sodashead01fl.unicph.domain:/path/to/file /path/to/destination

To move a text file from the H-drive on the server to your local documents folder, do:

scp abc123@sodashead01fl.unicph.doman:/ucph/hdir/test.txt /documents

docs.title: Setup
docs.text: The setup guide walks you through the process of setting up your developer environment on the SODAS server.

docs.title: SSH Config
docs.text:
Create a config file at ~/.ssh/config and add the following lines:

Host github.com
    HostName ssh.github.com
    PreferredAuthentications publickey
    IdentityFile ~/.ssh/id_ed25519
    Port 443

docs.title: Usage
docs.text: All usage of computer resources is manged through the Slurm1 Workload Manager.

docs.title: Slurm
docs.text:
Slurm is a job scheduler and resource manager for the compute resources available.

To start a simple interactive shell with 2 CPU cores, 5GB ram, 1 v100 GPU you can run the following command:

srun -w sodasgpun01fl --partition=gpuqueue \ #(1)!
    --ntasks-per-node=2 \ #(2)!
    --mem=5GB \ #(3)!
    --gres=gpu:v100:1 \ #(4)!
    --pty /bin/bash -i #(5)!
  1. Standard node and partition configuration
  2. Number of CPU copers
  3. Amount of memory (RAM)
  4. Number of GPUs
  5. Run task in pseudo terminal

docs.title: Jupyter Notebook
docs.text:
To start a Jupyter Notebook, you need to first allocate resources on the server:

srun -w sodasgpun01fl --partition=gpuqueue \
  --ntasks-per-node=2 \
  --mem=5GB \
  --pty /bin/bash -i

Then, load the Jupyter Notebook module:

module load jupyter-notebook/6.5.4

Now, you can start the notebook server:

jupyter notebook --port=8880 --ip=10.84.10.216 --no-browser

Then copy the generated link and paste it in your local computer's browsers.

I.e: http://10.84.10.216:8800/lab?token=abcd1234...
